newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australia govt says sure on Telstra sell down.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australia govt says sure on Telstra sell down.

text.p: Australia's conservative government said on Thursday it was confident of parliamentary approval for its planned sale of telecoms carrier Telstra Corp, but denied striking a deal with a Labor opposition defector.
"I am confident that we'll be able to persuade a majority of the (upper house) Senate in due course," Communications spokesman Richard Alston told Australian Broadcasting Corp television.
Alston said the government had not supported Labor rebel Mal Colston in his bid for the Senate deputy presidency in return for supporting the Telstra sell-off.
The Liberal-National government does not have a majority in the Senate and needs the support of at least two non-government senators to pass legislation.
Colston quit the Labor party on Tuesday to remain in the Senate as an independent, triggering speculation he could support the Telstra sale.
Announcing his resignation, Colston said he accepted government mandates to carry out promised reforms.
He was elected deputy president of the Senate on Tuesday after announcing his resignation.

Labor opposition communications spokesman Chris Schacht and Australian Democrats leader Cheryl Kernot said in the same interview they were not certain Colston had struck a deal to support the Telstra legislation.
Labor and the Democrats have pledged to vote against the legislation in the Senate.
Some senior government ministers have said Colston's defection makes Senate approval of the sell-off legislation easier.
But independent senator Brian Harradine told Australian Broadcasting Corp radio on Thursday that assessment could be wrong.
